thread.title: The Best Moments in College Football This Week
thread.title_full: The Best Moments in College Football This Week - The New York Times

author: The New York Times
title: The Best Moments in College Football This Week
text:
JORDAN CANZERI With No. 22 Iowa’s unbeaten season in peril, the Hawkeyes put the ball in the hands of their senior running back.
Canzeri, right, delivered with one of the best days a Hawkeye has ever had, helping his team hold off a furious challenge from visiting Illinois. Canzeri ran for 256 yards on a team-record 43 carries — including 11 straight on a crucial fourth-quarter drive — and Iowa beat the Illini, 29-20, for its sixth straight win.
“I thought what he did was really special,” said Coach Kirk Ferentz, who is 6-0 for just the second time in 17 seasons at Iowa. “Certainly in the fourth quarter. That was just a special effort.”
PATRICK MAHOMES AND JAKEEM GRANT Mahomes, Texas Tech’s sophomore quarterback, threw for 428 yards and five touchdowns, two of them to Grant, a senior wide receiver, to lead host Texas Tech past Iowa State, 66-31.
Continue reading the main story Related Coverage On College Football: With Upset, Texas Gives Coach Charlie Strong a Reprieve OCT. 10, 2015 Roundup: Facing Northwestern, Michigan Runs Shutout Streak to 3 OCT. 10, 2015 Beer Here! Beer Here? OCT. 8, 2015 Next Arms Race in Major Sports Is at the Food Table OCT. 6, 2015 Grant had a career-high 166 yards on nine catches. He caught scoring passes of 75 and 37 yards for the Red Raiders, his third game with more than 100 receiving yards of the season.
SHANNON BROOKS The Minnesota freshman running back gained 176 yards on 17 carries and changed the game with a 71-yard touchdown run early in the third quarter of a 41-13 blowout at Purdue.
DREW HARE Northern Illinois’s junior quarterback completed 29 of 32 passes for 363 yards and two touchdowns, and ran for one more, to lead the host Huskies over Ball State, 59-41.
THOMAS WOODSON Akron’s redshirt freshman quarterback threw four first-half touchdown passes as the Zips pummeled Eastern Michigan, 47-21, in Ypsilanti, Mich.
OHIO’S DEFENSE The Bobcats came up with four interceptions, including Quentin Poling’s 25-yard return for a touchdown, as Ohio routed Miami (Ohio), 34-3, at home.
News and Notes
COUGARS END FRUSTRATION Luke Falk threw for season-high 505 yards and five touchdowns, including an unusual scoring pass in double overtime, and visiting Washington State ended an eight-game losing streak against Oregon with a 45-38 victory.
Tied at 38, an unnecessary-roughness penalty against the Ducks helped the Cougars in the second overtime, and then Falk appeared to hit River Cracraft with a pass that landed in the hands of Robert Lewis for a 4-yard touchdown.
The play withstood review, and Oregon’s subsequent drive ended in an interception — sending the Cougars rushing onto the field in celebration.
Falk had marched the Cougars downfield in the final two minutes of regulation, capping the drive with an 8-yard pass to tie the game at 31 and send it to overtime.
NORTH TEXAS FIRES COACH The Mean Green (0-5) fired Coach Dan McCarney after they lost their homecoming game, 66-7, to Portland State of the Football Championship Subdivision.
McCarney was 22-32 in four-plus seasons with North Texas, including a victory in the Heart of Dallas Bowl against Nevada-Las Vegas after the 2013 season, when it finished 9-4.
North Texas Athletic Director Rick Villareal announced the move in a news release about an hour after the game.
Information from The Associated Press
